chapter.title: An Embedded Toolbox
chapter.summary: For a truly minimalist look, we can embed a toolbox into one of our window’s scroll bars.

section.p: Back in the late 1980s, when RISC OS was a new system, space on the screens of the day was limited and there was a trend for using minimalist toolboxes embedded into the space used by the scrollbars of a window. Of the numerous applications which used the technique, the original Ovation is still well-known – its take on the idea can be seen in .

image.title: The original Ovation put its toolbar where its scroll bar should have been

section.p: Back then, Ovation’s author achieved this effect using three windows all interleaved carefully. These days, the effect can be achieved more easily using the Nested Wimp, and in previous chapters we have already seen examples from Paint () and NetSurf () in passing.

As with the full-width toolbar that we created in , such toolboxes can be created using Furniture Windows. In this chapter, we will create ourselves a simple embedded toolbox in the bottom scroll bar of our window.

section.title: Updating the templates
section.p: Since we will be losing the toolbar at the top of our window, the first step to creating an embedded toolbox will be to reset our main window template back to the one that we created in : this will undo the changes to the work area that we made in . We will also delete the existing Toolbar template, leaving us with just the Main and ProgInfo window definitions as seen in .

image.title: The clean set of templates from the original demo application

section.p: The next step is to create ourselves a new window for the embedded toolbox. We’ll call this “Embedded”, and it can be seen being edited by WinEd in . Since we will be sizing and positioning it to fit into the scroll bar of our main window, there is no point adjusting its dimensions for now. The title has been set to “Toolbox”, but it doesn’t matter as it won’t be seen.

image.title: The new window template for the embedded toolbox

section.p: The window flags need to be set in a similar manner to our previous toolbars: turn off all of the window furniture (title bar, scroll bars and so on), and turn on the furniture flag. The settings in WinEd can be seen in .

image.title: The original Ovation put its toolbar where its scroll bar should have been

section.p: With these changes in place, we can now close the templates and move on to updating the program itself.
